div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: REFORM IN RUSSIA.
div.p: A very interesting telegram from St. Petersburg this morning announces that the Russian. Government actually gave permission for a public conference to be held at St. Petersbarg, composed of representatives of "Zems tvos" throughout the country. At the last moment, however, the courage of the autocracy failed, and the sanction for a public con ference was withdrawn, though the delegates were allowed to meet in private A more portentous step. in the history of the poli tical emancipation of the human race has not occurred since the summoning of the States General. The analogy can be pressed further. The weakness of the Government is quite on a par with the foolish precedents set by the Ministers of Louis XVI, who alternatively showed their distrust and weakness in the step they had taken. The Russian Government first accedes to a most important political step and then at the last moment withdraws ite sanction. But instead of putting an absolute veto on the conference it allows the representatives of the Zemstvos to meet in private. The consequences were obvious Radical resolutions are adopted, a Constitution is demanded, together with liberty of conscience, liberty of the Press, liberty of speech, sad liberty of education, besides an elective legislative assembly. This private conference was only held on Saturday, but by Monday the facts are known to the world" and the ball has been set rolling which, under the leadership of a Slavonic Mirabeau or Lafayette, may lead to the ruin of militant autocracy throughout the Russian Empire:

At the same time, serious observers of the conditions of modern Russia, even among those who sympathise with the aspirations of the Russian people for a form of government which will give some legitimate scope for their ener gies, entertain grave doubts as to the capacity of the Rumians for self-government. The members of the bureaucracy, indeed, base their claim to govern Russia, when they condescend to argue the matter at all; on the ground that no other government is possible. Soon after his acceptance of office the new Minister of the Interior made a mentorable declaration."Abroad," said Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski, "people speak of new Constitution for Russia: such a thing is, impossible under present conditions." It is not only abroad that people speak of a new Constitu tion; it is in Busia itself that the demand is being made. But Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski's declaration, did not stop short at a repetition of the common official formula. "Bat," be continged, "there is such a thing as local self-government, as is exemplified in the Zemstvos. I believe," he added, "in Zematvos." That is a declaration of immense importance coming from such aquarter how important is demonstrated, with singular appositeness in an article on "Self government in Russia" in the new number of the Empire Review. For reasons which may readily be sur mised, the writer of the article desires to pre serve his anonymity; but internal evidence renders almost superfluous the editorial a surance that the writer is entitled to be listened to with respect when he seeks to supplement Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski's statemont by giving a sketch of the Zemstvo institution in Rassia The evidence which is adduced of the existence of the seeds of a representative system of government throughout the greater part of European Russia is derived mainly from official sources But it may be said with some confidence that it will be for the most part new, to Western Europe. The existence of the Zemstvo system was, of course, a matter of common know ledge; what is now is the extent to which it appears to have taken root in Russian provin cial life, the success which has on the whole attended it, and the possibilities which it presents of preparing the people for the difficult task of self-government. The Zemstvo instita-- tion is a tiny plant, but if it be wisely tended it may yet grow into a noble tree. Unfortunately Prince Sviatopolk-Mirski's belief in the Zemst vos is not a common article of bureaucratio faith, and there have been indications that, if some of the bureaucrats of St. Petersburg could have their way' even this struggling experiment in local self government would be crashed beneath the heel of autocracy. But the fact that the delegates of the Zemstvos were allowed. even to confer in private on Saturday last is an historical event of the utmost significance, and we may live to reckon November 19, 1904, as one of the cardinal dates in the history of the human race

div.head:
THE WAR.
JAPS BLOWN UP.
ALL QUIET IN MANCHURIA.
div.p: General Kuropatkin reports that, during the night of the 16th inst., four volunteers with pyroxyline bombs blew up a Chinese building on the Russian left, which was occupied by 25 Japanese. The latter were all killed or wounded, and were buried in the débris. With this exception, all is quiet in Manchiria. (Reuter)

div.head:
PORT ARTHUR.
ERHLUNG-SHAN FORT.
COUNTERSCARP OCCUPIED.
THE RUSSIAN SORTIE,

div.p: The Japanese mined and occupied the counterscarp of Erhlung-shan Fort on the 19th inst.
The Japanese have mined and occupied the counterscarp of Erhlung shan Fort at Poit Arthur on the 19th inst.

The Daily Telegraph understands from Shanghai that a steamer from Chi-tu reports the news that four Russian destroyers, includ ing the Hastorpny, carrying identical des patches, left Port Arthur at the same time. The Japanese stopped two. The fate of the third is unknown: Their orders were to deliver the despatches at Chi-fu at any cost. (Reuter

div.head: JAPS SEIZE GERMAN STEAMER.
div.p: The Japanese have seized and taken to Sasebo the German steamer Batelan, which was making for Port Arthur with a cargo of water clothing, bankets, medicines, and corned beef. The captain declared that the vessel was bound for Ningchwang (Reuter.)

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
OUTRAGES AT CANEA.
OFFICERS AND MEN RUN AMOK
FIVE PERSONS MURDERED.
div.p: The Daily Express learns from Canea that some of the officers and men of the Baltic Fleet have roamed the streets of the town in a state of wild intoxication, insulting and assaulting the inhabitants. During the drunken brawls they murdered at least five persons. Forty Russians have deserted. (Reuter)

div.head: OUTRAGE ON HUNGARIAN PREMIER. ASSAILED WITH SNOWBALLS
div.p: Count Tisza, the Hungarian Premier, whilst leaving a meeting at which he had justified the policy of the Government, was received by a noisy crowd with cries of "Resign." He was assaulted with snowballs. The police dispersed the crowd with blank cartridges, and arrested forty persons. (Reuter.)

div.head: DEVASTATING BORE. 30,000 PEOPLE HOMELESS
div.p: A bore has devastated the Taloet archipelago. Thirty thousand people are homeless.

div.head:
A NEW RUSSIA!
DAWN OF NEW ERA.
CONSTITUTION DEMANDED,
div.p: As a result of Prince Minskin' appointment the Government gave permission for a public conference to be held here of representatives from the Zemistvos throughout the country, but at the last moment declined to sanction the same, thongh allowing the delegates to meet privately. The Government forbade the newspapers to mention the matter. The delegates met last Saturday privately, and adopted radical resolutions demanding a constitution, an elective legislative assembly, together with liberty of conscience, press, speech, and education. (Reuter.)

div.head: STRAY AND OWNERLESS DOGS
div.p: found in the Ramleh and Moharrem Bey districts, on the 23rd inst. will be poisoned by the police

div.head: THE PILGRIMAGE.
div.p: Dr. Hayes, of the Quarantine Service, has arrived at Alexandria from Suez on important duty connected with the forthcoming pilgrimage.

div.head: OPERA SEASON.-
div.p: The drawing for boxes and stalls in the Zizinia Theatre for the coming operatic season will take place at the Khedivial Bourse st 6.15 p.m. to-day.

div.head: THE RAILWAY COMMISSION
div.p: arrived at Alexandria last night and inspected the Bab-el-Ghedid station this morning. It is expected the quays will be visited this afternoon.

div.head: THE ASILE RUDOLPH
div.p: gratefully acknowledges with thanks the receipt of a quantity of bread and sandwiches for the use of the poor from Messrs. Walker and Meimarachi, Ltd.

div.head: SUPREME CONSULAR COURT.-
div.p: Judge de Sausmarez returned from Cairo yesterday. A Maltese maintenance case was heard before him this morning in the Supreme Consular Court..

div.head: STABBING AFFRAY:-
div.p: In the course of a brawl between four natives in a coffee shop in Moharrem Bey yesterday, two were seriously stabbed. They were conveyed to hospital, and the two others arrested.

div.head: GAMBLING HELL RAID.
div.p: The Alexandria police, with the aid of the Hellenic Consulate, made a raid on a gambling-hell in Nubar Pasha-street on Sunday night and arrested the owner, the cards and money being seized.

div.head: HOSPITAL SUPPLIES-
div.p: The adjudication for the supply of provisions to the Kasr-el-Aini Hospital, the infectious diseases hospital, and the lunatic asylum, not having given satisfactory results, it will be renewed on the 10th December next.

div.head: EGYPTIAN STATE RAILWAYS-
div.p: The Board of Administration informs us that, from Thursday, 1st proximo, a dining car will be attached daily to No. 5 train leaving Shellal for Luxor at 9.10 a.m., and to No. 6 train leaving Luxor for Shellal at 10 am.

div.head: MENAGERIE.-
div.p: The stay of Masserini's Menagerie at Alexandria is, drawing to a close. No one should miss seeing the serpentine dance, executed by Mme Masserini in the midst of a group of lions. In other respects, also, the show is well worth a visit.

div.head: ALHAMBRA THEATRE-
div.p: The Castellano Italian opera company commenced its return visit on Saturday with Manon Lescaut, which was successfully produced, as also were Hamlet on Sunday and Gioconda last night. This evening Un Ballo in Manchera will be given.

div.head: DELTA LIGHT RAILWAY.
div.p: The committee of the London Stock Exchange has ordered the following security to be quoted in the official List. Egyptian Delta Light Railways Company, further issue of £107,000 4. percent Debentures of £100 each, Nos. 3,531 to 4,600.

div.head: ATTEMPTED MURDER
div.p: A Greek (local subject) fired at and seriously wounded a compatriot in the Mir Ganeh quarter of Alexandria. The would be murderer, on being arrested, stated that he had fired in self-defence as his victim had attempted to kill him. No hope is entertained of the latter's recovery.

div.head: VERDE THEATRE,
div.p: The alterations made in the Verdi Theatre were completed yesterday, and the house should now be perfectly secure against all danger of fire. The Italian opera company now performing at the Abbas Helmy Theatre will go up to Cairo shortly and give a series of performances there till the end of February

div.head: THE KHEDIVE
div.p: The Khedive is still on his estates at Montazah.
His Highness has been graciously pleased to bestow the following ranks on the under mentioned officials:
Sanieh: Nicolas Sawaya Bey, ex-postmaster of Tantah.
Salissah: Salib Nakhla Effendi, ex-chief accountant of the province of Sharkieh, and Iskandar Khalil Effendi, ex-station-master at Suez
Rabea: Maximos Youssef Effendi, ex-chief accountant of the province of Gharbieh.

His Highness has conferred the rank of officer (4th class) of the Imperial Order of the Medjidieh on M. Giuseppe di Giorgio, ex-chef de bureau at the Alexandria Post Office, and the rank of Chevalier (3th class) on M. Giovanni Cortessi, ex chef de bureau at the Alexandria Post Office.

div.head: COUNCIL OF MINISTERS
div.p: The Council of Ministers, under the presidency of H. H. the Khedive, will meet on Saturday afternoon at Abdeen Palace, to discuss the provisions of next year's Budget. The modifications in the ranks of the engineers in the Ministry of Public Works will also be considered.

div.head: HEDJAZ RAILWAY.
div.p: Marshal Kiarim Pasha, director of the works of the Hedjar Railway, has telegraphically communicated to the High Commission for that line a summary of the contents of the chief engineer's report on the work done during the past month, beyond Maan. According to this report, the work is making good progress both as regards the earthworks and the building of bridges and tunnels. The boring of tunnels Nos. 1 and 5 is very shortly to be taken in band. Tunnel No. 2 has been bored, No. 3 has been commenced, No. 4 is practically finished, and No. 6 is completely finished.

div.head: SHEIKH BARGHUT. THE SANGANEB REEF.
div.p: The Sanganeb reef lies about 13 miles eastward of Sheikh Barghut harbour, and it is essential that a lighthouse should be erected on this reef, if Sheikh Barghut is to be the chiet harbour on the Egyptian side of the Red Sea. The Ports and Lighthouses Administration have decided, therefore, to erect a lighthouse on the southern portion of the reef. It is to be an open iron-work tower and the height of the focal line above high water will be 165 feet. The light is to be of the first order, showing all round. The type of lamp is to be petroleum burning. Quarters for four lightkeepers are to be constructed.

div.head: CATTLE EXPORTS TO EGYPT.
div.p: Our Constantinople Correspondent states that the reason why the Uttoman Government has decided to temporarily prohibit the export of cattle to Egypt is owing to the enormous rise in the price of seat consequent on these exports, especially in the vilayet of Aidin.

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: The Khedive has been most graciously pleased to approve of the following promotions, from dates stated:-
Local Kaimakam St. C. M. G. MacEwen Bey, Sudan Civil Adininistration, to be Kaimakam, 2-7-04
El Bimbashi H. G. A. Garsia, D.S.O., Staff Officer for Supplies, Sudan South, to be Kaimakam, 1-10-4.
El Bimbashi S. L. Cummins, Medical Corps, to be Local Kaimakam, 1-11-04

div.head: THEFTS AT LUXOR
div.p: In the course of his recent lecture at the Egyptian Institute on the discoveries at Karnak, M. G. Legrain dealt with the theft perpetrated at Luxor. The inspector of the Antiquities Service informed his hearers that, thanks to the measures taken, the two fine statues had been recovered. The thieves were run to earth and punished. All had been premeditated in this theft, and it was within their knowledge who had paid the thieves £10 to carry it out. The speaker hoped that the Antiquities Service would receive a certain amount of support from the native judges in the adequate punishment of antiquity thieves.

div.head: KORDOFAN TRADING COMPANY, LTD.
div.p: This company has been registered with a capital of £6,100 in 6,000 shares of £1 each and 2,000 shares of 1s each, to carry on in the United Kingdom and in Egypt, Kordofan, and the neighbouring provinces, or in any part of Africa, the business of general merchants, traders in, and purchasers of ivory, ostrich feathers, rubber and other products, import and export merchants, etc.. The office of the company is at 46, Leadenhall-street, Landon, C.E

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE-
div.p: The November issue of the monthly Bulletin of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt is, as usual, full of interesting information. The contents include extracts from a paper on moisture in cotton and cotton yarn, recently read before the New England Cotton Manufacturers Association, summaries of the consular reports issued by H.M.'s representatives at Alexandria, Port Said, and Suez and many useful remarks and feets in regard to exports, cotton, cotton seed, beans, freights, company meetings, Egyptian imports, traffic on the Mahmoudieh Canal, contracts, course of exchange stocks and shares, coal imports, dividends and reports, conversion tables, etc.

div.head:
THE GREEK FLEET.
ARRIVAL AT PORT SAID.
div.p: Great preparations have been made to welcome and entertain the Greek Squadron during its visit to Port Said, where it is due to arrive to-morrow morning from Alexandria.
A reception committee has been formed, the members being Messrs. Coroni, Roidis, Smyrniadis, Pneumaticos, and Kantazis.
According to the programme drawn up at present, on Monday evening Commodore Coundouristis, his staff, and principal officer will be entertained at dinner by Mr. Coroni.

On Tuesday morning a "Te Deum" will be celebrated at the Greek Church, which will be attended by the officers and men. A grand banquet will be given to the Commodore and officers at the Continental Hotel in the evening, covers being laid for 100.
The fleet may possibly leave on Wednesday or at the latest on Thursday. There is a report that the Russian Fleet will not arrive till after the departure of the Greek Squadron,
The Greek Fleet arrived at Port-Said about 10 o'clock this morning and saluted the port, the salute being returned by the battery.

As soon as the vessels were signalled the Greek colony made holiday, and assembled in thousands on the breakwater and along the Quai François Joseph, to welcome their com patriots. Several crowded launches, on the largest of which (the Ibis) was the reception committee and a band playing national airs, went out to meet the ships and accompanied them to their moorings. Shortly after, the usual official calls were paid.
Greek flags and decorations are in evidence everywhere, Port-Said possessing a large Greek community.

div.head: GREEK FLEET LOTTERY
div.p: The Hellenic Minister of Finance has sent 50,000 tickets to Egypt for the Greek Fleet Lottery. It is believed that more than 100,000 tickets will be taken in Egypt

div.head: MOTORS FOR EGYPT.
div.p: Prince Djemil Toussoun has ordered a double phaeton body, to be sent to Egypt for his Panhard "châssis," from Botiaux, of Levallois.
Comte Michel de Zogheb has purchased an eight horse power three-cylinder Panhard automobile, with landaulet body by Labourdette.

div.head: PUBLIC WORKS.
div.p: The adjudication of 1st instant-relative to the annual works of repairing, etc., to be carried out in the canals and drains of the Behera province has been approved in favour of the following contractors:--

div.head: SILVAIN IN CAIRO
div.p: Papa Lebonsard is not a great drama, but it was admirably performed on Saturday night, at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo, when the house gave the veteran actor, M. Silvain, a very warm welcome. Comparisons are always odious, especially when two such different schools of acting as those represented by M. Coquelin Ainé and M. Silvain are discussed, but the difference in the style of the two men is very remarkable. M. Silvain is a master of declamation, his utterance of verse always ore rotundo, and his interpretation of the title role is thoroughly human, but in Louis XI he seems to us to exaggerate a little the human weakness of the king threatened by the dagger of Nemours. It is possible to argue that in this moment the king is only a frightened animal, but it is equally permissible to contend that even in such a moment of terror and dismay certain relics of the kingly dignity would still enable Louis to present a more royal front to his foe.

div.head: COTTON KING SOLD UP
div.p: The office furniture of Mr. Sally, the great cotton speculator, was sold by auction at New York last week in connection with his bankruptcy. It realised only £1,500, although is must have cost twice as much.

div.head: GHEZIREH PALACE
div.p: The management of Ghezireh Palace and Shepheand's Hotel have decided, owing to the large nituber of applications for rooms, to re-open the Ghezireh Palace on December 15. We near that many improvements have been made at Ghezireh. The west balcony has been enlarged, and nothing has been spared to make the park worthy of its world-wide reputation.
A new Trigane orchestra of 12 performers, one of the best which Budapest possesses, has been engaged by the general management of both hotels for the season.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The S. S. Bolderas, of the Westcott and Laurance Line, left Malta yesterday and is due here, on Friday with general cargo, from London.
The Ellerman S.S. Ararat sailed from Malta on Monday, and is due here with passengers mails, and general cargo on Friday morning
The Khedivial Mail 8. & Prince Abbas will leave Alexandria on Wednesday, for Piraus, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.

div.head:
THE BALTIC FLEET.
SUEZ CANAL PASSAGE.
LIKELIHOOD OF ATTACK IN LOCAL WATERS
div.p: It is now understood that the Baltic Fleet will reach Port Said on Wednesday next at dawn. The Fleet, which is under the commsad of Vice Admiral Volkerahm, will number 30 vessels, comprising 2 battleships, 2 cruisers, 7 destroyers, 5 stemem of the Volunteer Fleet, and 4 German colliers. Arrangements have been made for a prompt supply of coal, water, and provisions, sufficient to carry them to the next port of call.
During their stay at Port Said a police patrol, will be drawn round the vessels, defining limit beyond which all unauthorised persons will not be allowed.
The Canal authorities are quite confident that they can pass the fleet through to Suez without great hindrance to the ordinary merchant traffic

It is very necessary to emphatically deny the ridiculous reports which have been circulated by mischief-makers from time to time, respecting a probable attack upon the Russian Fleet in Egyptian waters by the Japanese or their emissaries, such having not the slightest foundation in fact.

On Sunday, last even official sources fixed the arrival of the fleet for the following Monday. A space on the Asistic side of the canal was cleared of all shipping, so that the nerves of the fleet might not be un- duly strained by the presence of felucas, barges, or other formidable craft Special pilots were also warned for duty. It is now reported that the Russian Consal has advised the Canal Company officials that the fleet will not arrive until Saturday next. It has struck more than one, that it is a good deal safer for this fleet, composed as it is of old ships (barring the dan troyers) to await the arrival in the Indian Ocean of the main fleet before venturing past Aden alone.
Referring to the passage of the ships throngh the Suez Canal, the Loudon Morning Post says:–

In regard to the reported resolution of the Egyptian authorities to permit vessels of the Russian Baltic Fleet, of which there are now a number off Crete or approaching the Levant, to take provisions and coal at Port Said suffi cient to "enable them to reach the next port," it is to be remarked that this is wholly at variance with the Suez Canal regulations. The first three clauses of those regulations relate to the passage of men-of-war in what may be termed ordinary circumstances. The next three bear on the question of such warships' stay in the Ca nal. But the seventh clause expressly provides that no vessel belonging to a belligerent Power shall embark "warlike stores, supplies, or equip ment" in the Suez Canal or "any of its ports of access," meaning Port Said or Suez, and perhaps Ismailia. Obviously the Suez Canal authorities will infringe their own regulations in adopting the course towards the Baltic Fleet which they are reported to have in con- templation. As for Egyptian porta other than those of access to the Suez Canal, they are covered by another regulation which prohibits any belligerent resorting to any such Egyptian port or roadstead for the purpose of obtaining "any facilities for warlike equipment." If Egypt chooses to enforce her own regulations it will be impracticable for the Baltic Fleet to coal in her waters, and it is above all to be borne in mind that the intention of the law is not in any case that coal should be supplied wherewith to continue the voyage Eastward in a hostile expedition against a Power friendly to Egypt, but to enable the vessels to reach the nearest Russian port. The expedition is bound away from, not towards, its own coun- try's shores. Egypt appears to be classed by Russia among the Powers which may have the will but have not the strength to refuse aid, though it should constitute a breach of neutrality. But there is a Power that stands behind Egypt, and that Power has given proof of its resolve that neutrality shall be observed; therefore the Japanese will take leave to doubt if the intention with which the Suez Canal Company is credited will be carried out.

It is not precisely that Japan apprehends danger from the continuance of the voyage of the Baltic Squadrons, or their possible reunion asone Armada somewhere south of the equator, but because it would form & bad procedent were the Suez Canal to be made the scene of a gross infringement of the obligations imposed on neutrals is impossible to say what inter- national difficulties might not arise were the door to be opened to systematic infraction of the privileges which, in virtue of a strict observance of neutrality, a Power like Egypt enjoys. The idea of an organised attack by Japanese desperadoes, if wach individuals are to be found in this beinisphere, on the Russian ships during their passage through the famous Heyptian waterway is too absurd to merit the least attention. It would be nearer the mark perhaps, if the vivid imagination of Russian men of war's men should prepare them for the spectacle of vast fleets of Chinese junks blocking the passage of the squadrons through narrow Eastern channels-the Straits of Sunda or the Formos Channel as. examples-with Japaneis torpedo craft dashing forth from behind the shelter this afforded and sinking their foes right and left. The Russians could enly thank themselves for having given the Japanese the original idea as derived from the phantoms of the North S

div.head: BRITISH CRUISER AT SUEZ
div.p: The British cruiser Pe has arrived here from Trinhomall

div.p: Prince Humain Pain R for Chino yesterday afternoon
We regret to of the Maldives Bea locomotor ataxy, and

Best Admiral Sir Matie Blomf Controller-General of the Ports Administration, and Lady Bloo yesterday from Cairo
The St. James's Gazette states that M Rembold, on of Sir Horse Rambold the composer of the entr'acte music for week's production in London of Mt. Craigie's The Flute of Pan"
The marriage of Mille Benée Army, daughter of M. and Mme Emin Amy Bey, to Henry Goarmo will take place at the Church of the Nativity, Bacok, on Saturday next

Marquis Salvago-Raggi amived at Cairo on Sunday from Italy.

Mr. Carl Otto Montan, Judge at the Mixed Tribunal of 1st Instance, Maneourah, has been transferred in the same capacity to the Alex andria Mixed Tribunal of 1st Instance

div.head: OMDEH MURDERED.
div.p: The omdeh of El-Aghaneh, a wealthy man, held in high esteem in Tahta district, while on his way home on the evening of the 18th inst, accompanied by another omdeh and the sarral of El-Aghanaeh, was sadden by accosted by three armed men. They met him nearly half way between his village and Tema, where he had been attending an assembly, presided over by the police officer. One of the three armed men, known afterwards to be Bakit Ha

rushed towards the omdeh and stabbed him in the face. His two companions were threatened with the same fate should they utter any ery or give help. One of the two companione knew the first assailant by name, and, being named both took to their heels. The victim resisted to the last. The first blow be received clean aliend off his nose, the second out amay four inges, the last broke his skull. The post-morte examination shows that the victim received ten serious blows before he was slain.

The ghaffir belonging to the victim's owa village was in Tama together with the omdeh but he had slackened pace and could not keep ap with his master. When he did reach the spot where the victim lay, he found him dead and saw Bakit Hassanein crossing the canal with two other men unknown to him.

News of the occurrence reached her, and Hilmy Bey Issa, the Substitut du Parquet, together with the medical inspector, proceeded to the spot. They were joined by the Ine pector for the Interior and the Sab Moudir. An inquiry was opened, and Bakit Hamein, the suspected perpetrator of the crime, haa been arrested.
The man arrested in known throughout the district as a most brutal character. He has been brought several times before the Geurts for crime.

div.head: NOTES FROM HELOUAN.
div.p: Helouan, Monday-The dust of the long summer months has been effectively laid to-day by a sharp shower of 10 minutes, when 2 mil limetros of rain fell. The atmosphere has als been cleared of dust, and the desert air is now as crisp and bracing as one could wish for.
A company of Royal Engineers are encamped behind the Tewfik Palace Hotel for the annual field exercises
The hotels and pensions are all open now, looking bright and clean, ready for the season visitors. George Nungovich Bey is to be congratulated on the new ball he has added to the Grand Hotel.

The garden of the Tewik Palace Hotel is looking beautifully green just now. Amongst the already numerous guests staying at this well-known hotel I notice Baron and Baroness de Gordon-Coldwells, Miss O'Callaghan, Miss H. Gordon, Rev. Patrick Buckley, Mr. A. S Wylie, Dr. Beddoe, Capt. Bigge, R.E, Lieut. Clogstoun, and Lieut. James
Amongst those expected shortly are, General and Mrs. Fred Lance, Miss Smail, Mrs. H. W Finch, Mr. and Mrs. E. Bullock Workman, Mr. and Mrs. Wood, Mr. H. Lory, etc.

Loud are the praises of the, cooking this season at the Tewtik Palace Hotel, I believe the services of the chef and kitchen staff of one of the best sanatoria in Switzerland have been secured by the management.

div.head: LES PROTETS EN EGYPTE
div.p: A un moment donné la question des protits a captivé l'attention de la presse égyptienne, des juristes et des chambres de commerce. Leare avis étaient partagés, mais un point sur lequel tous étaient d'accord, c'était celui de réduire le coût du protés, qui; comme on le sait, s'élève à 58 r.T. sans compter les frais de déplacement de l'huissier. En effet, k protét, pour être logique, devrait être établi proportionnellement au montant d l'effet et non sur une base unique de 68 P.T., que la traite soit d'ailleurs d'une ou de cent livres égyptiennes.
Mais si le prix du protés est excessif pour les effets de moindre valeur, nous ne eroyons pas qu'il en soit ainsi pour les satres et voici pourquoi:

Le nombre de traites annuellement protestées au tribunal d'Alexandrie egs de 2,500 à 3,000, sans comptér les effets protestés aux divers consalats de la ville et su Iribunal indigèse. Bar os chiffre, deus cente traites seulement ont des suites en justice et le nombre de poursuites en décis ration de faillite est bien plus faible encore Pourqaci dons cette habitude de 1-inser protester des billets qu'on a l'intention di payer ensuite? Le motif en est bien simpl et les commerç sats qui sont à court d'ar geat le comprendront tout de suite. Les formalités du protêt sont fort longues; sor enregistrement, son retrait par la Banqu chargée de l'encaissement, son envoi aux fabricants d'Europe, son renvoi par eni à leurs représentante ou à leurs avocats en Egypte, le temps que ceux-ci metient par fois à encaisser, tout cela prend souvent jusqu'à six mole. On comprendés que pou un négociant syant besoin de disponibi lités le moyen le plus économique d'e avoir à sa di-position est de laisser protester ses traites: Moyennant 58-P.T. d. protat et quelques menus frais, il opère pendant des mois sur des sommes de 10 A 200 livres qui, s'il eft du les einprunter, lai endent oudté un intérés bien supérieur.
Voilà pourquoi des négociants égyptiene continueront à laisser protest r kas trai tes et qu'il n'y a pas lies, par les fortes sommes du moine, de réduire le prix du proté

div.head: La Conference Judiciaire
div.p: Si'il faut en eroire an de nos confrères, dans les deux réunions qui ont eu lieu la semaine passée à Alexandrie, la sous- Commission judiciaire s'est occupée de la question de la soppression do tribunal mixte de Mansdarah. Tout en laissant le gouvernement libre d'obéir à d'autra considérations d'ordre politique ou adminis tratif,elle sémis, au point de vae judicisire, un avis favorable à l'opportunité de la suppression de sa tribanal. En so qui concerne le renouvellem at 'des pouvoirs de la Béformé pendani un an, tout en laissant aux agents diplomaciques le soin de se prononcer en dernier ressort, elle eroit bon de proposer is prorogation des pouvoirs pendant un an afin de permettre aux membrie de la Commission d'étudier à fond les modifiations à elle soumises par la gouvernement et de les adopter, s'il y a lieu,pour le proch sin renouvellement quinquennal des pouvoirs de la Réforme. La Commission s'est mise également d'accord sur le projes d'expropriation pour eaus d'atilité pobliques et un rapporteur à été chargé de coordonner les articles du projet avee los modifestions apporté

Es qui eon orne, toutefois, la sup pression da tribunal, de Mansourah, nous apprinoos de sogres autorisée que la quition n'a pas encore été abordée. Ls proshsins réunion de la Commission technique sara lieu su Oaire le lundi qui suivre les fêtes du Batram.

div.head: La fin d'un conflit
div.p: Le Cadi vient de reconnaitre à l'Administration des Wakfs le droit exclusif de contrôler la gestion des directeurs des Wakf de bienfairane, contrôle que le Mehkemeh Charieh prétendait se réserver. Pour trancher ce différend entre les deux grandes administrations indigènes, le Cadi s'es basé sur le chapitre VII du règlemen promalgué en juillet 1895.

Les ministres, réunis dimanche sous la présidence du Khédive, ont approuvé la solution donnée à l'incident soulevé à prorops des comptes des nazirs. C'est sinai que le conflit entre les deux grandes administrations se trouve enfin splani.

div.head: Conference Silvain
div.p: M. Silvain, l'éminent sociétaire de la comédie française, professeur au Conservatoire de Paris, a bien voulu donner un Conférence sur l'Art de dire, sous le patronagé et à la demande du Comité de l'Uniseraité populaire.
Cette conférence aura lieu vendredi prochain 25 Novembre à 5 h précises p.m. Jane la grande salle du New-Khedivial Hotel.

Les billets d'entrés sont en vente à l'U- niversité populaire, aux librairies L. Scholer et Nacamali et ag magasin de cartes postales Kardische, raé Chérif pachs. Le produit de cette conférence est coneseré entièrement aux frais des cours de Université populaire.

div.head: BULLETIN DE LA BOURSE
div.p: Le marché est légèrement oppressé. Le mou vement s'est concentré sur les Cotton Mills qui atteignent 8/3 acheteurs et la Salt & Soda qui fléchit à 39/3.

La plupart des valeurs accusent une baisse sensible, la Banque Nationale à 24 1/8 l'Agricole à 10 15/16, la Béhéra à 55 1,2, la Delta Land à 3 11/16, la Nungovich à 9 1/16, la Delta Light à 15 3/16, et la Ramleh Railway A87/16
Par contre il y a hausse de l'Anglo Ame rican Nile à 33,8, des Eaux d'Alexandrie à 17, des Eaux du Caire à 1100 et des Privilégiées Tramways à 147 1/2.

div.head: ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK.
div.p: The report of the Directors of the Anglo- Egyptian Bank will be presented at the eighteenth ordinary general meeting of the company which will be held at the Bank, 27, Clement's Lane, London, this afternoon. The report shows that for the year, ended the 31st August last, the gross profits, after making provi sion for all bad debts and contingencies, amount ed to £146,329 14. 11d; and deducting the expenses, amounting to £46,898 18s. 1d., there remains a balance of £99,430.16s. 10d, net profit for the year. To this amount must be added £17,000, the balance carried forward on the 21st August, 1903, making £116,430 16 10d, which the Directors.propose should be dealt with in the following manner-Contribution to staff provident fund, £1,430 16s. 10d., interim dividend at 10 per cent. per annum, paid 1st June, £20,000, dividend at 15 per cent. per annum, to be paid on 1st December, £30,000, transfer to reserve fund, £50,000, balance carried forward, £15,000, making a total of £116,430, 16, 10d.

In accordance with the articles of association, Mr. Alan Richardson retires from the Board, and being eligible will offer himself for reelection. Messrs. Cooper Brothers and Co. will offer themselves for re-election as auditors. The balance sheet (31st August) is as follows:

His children include three, sets of triplets and one of quadruplets by his first wife, as well as five aire of twins by his second wife.

div.head: EGYPTIAN COTTON.
div.p: The present conditions of the Egyptian market and the relative values of Egyptian and American cotton are attracting considerable attention. In some respects these conditions are quite abnormal. At the beginning of the season chop expectations ran as high as 4 7,000,000 cantars. Inasmuch as last season's t erop of 6,508,947 cantars, plus a carry-over of t 69,000 cantars, left a stock in Alexandria on t August 31 last of 409,000 cantars, despite te profitable trade in Egyptian yarns, lower prices H seemed inevitable. The trade acted accordingly, and contracted ahead for cotton very sparingly d indeed. As the season developed crop conditions deteriorated, and have continued to do so, until quite well-informed houses no longer look for a larger crop than 6,250,000 cantars, and some even 6,000,000 cantars. The holders and controllers of stocks in Egypt, from the natives to the large financial institutions, have been unwilling sellers, with the result that Egyp tian cotton has advanced both absolutely and in comparison with American. The advance is larger in the interior than in Alexandria, whilst that market, in turn, is well above the parity of the Liverpool market. It is obvious, therefore, that this market has stood, and presently stands, at a disadvantage, for attracting stocks.

Now the spinning conditions in. England as regards Egyptian cotton are the exact contrary to those which obtained last season, Paving become so very unsatisfactory that spindles are being turned from Egyptian on to American cotton, and mills newly built for the production of Egyptian yarn are similarly chang ing their intention in favour of American, more particularly in view of the brilliant prospects now enjoyed by spinners of that growth of cotton. The immediate prospects, therefore, are for a consumption of Egyptian cotton considerably less than that of last season. In due time, doubtless, the law of supply and demand will assert itself, and probably when Egypt endeavours to réalise a considerable recession from present prices will ensue. Meantime, the Liverpool market is interested in the fact that the high prices of Egyptian cotton have provoked a considerable line of "striddles"-by sale of Egyptian and purchase of Ariserican cotton-an operation which so far has proved unprofitable by the continuous widening of Egyptian from American cotton. As concerns "near" cotton, this disparity is more pronounced on the one side by the decline in Americas on the favourable crop promise and rapid accumulation of stock here, and on the other by the extreme scarcity of tenderable Egyptian cotton in the market. In view of the speculative sentiment pervad ing Egypt just now it is doubtful if the dis parity has yet reached its extremity, although it is hoped that for the sake of the Egyptian section of the spinning trade, now comparat ively unfavourably situated, the Egyptian marketa may soon be restored to normal and non-speculative conditions.

div.head: SUAKIN NOTES.
div.p: The Sudan Government 83. Mukhbir arrived yesterday evening from Sues and brought with her several steel barges for the Sudan Rail. way, besides a large quantity ofother material for the railway.

The Port steam tng Hawke (Captain Taglis ferro, late of the Khedivial Mail Line) leaves to-day for Suez and will, on arrival there, go into dry dock for painting and general repairs. Another big shower of rain came down yesterday but has done no damage worth noting, except to the new railway line, which is slightly damaged.

The Suakin International Club, which was opened some time ago, is doing well, and its members have greatly increased. Its supporters Are the leading merchants of Suakin, and they thoroughly enjoy the club during the dull winter evenings. Some sports and boating moos are being got up. A swimming bath in attached to the club

Graham's Point is very lively now. It has become quite a little colony with the cottages for workmen built by the Railways. A coffee shop and canteen have sprung op, and, in less than a year a desert has been trasformed into a boxy European colony. The Arab workmen also enjoy the bright English cottages, which they have never seen before.

div.head: COST OF LIVING IN EGYPT.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE Sir, I was greatly interested in reading the list of comparative prices published in the Gazette to-day, and I quite sympathise with the employés of the Ministry of Finance in their attempt to get the Minister to bring up their salaries so as to be proportionate to the enormous,increase in the cost of living which has taken place only recently. But the employés of the Ministry of Finance, had no need to compare the present year with 1885. They might have only gone back five years. But it is quite easy even to show that since last year the cost of living has greatly increased in Alexandria For example, I pay now P.C. 6 per oke of sugar; last year I only paid P.C. 3) per oke. Ordinary coffee last year was P.C. 11 per oke, I have now to pay P.C. 14. Last year I used to pay P.C. 2 for seven eggs. I cannot get eggs to-day for less than P.C. 2 for four. Last year petroleum was P.C. 11 s safieh, but this year I have paid as much as P.C. 22. Milk has not fluctuated in price and pay P.C. 4 and 5 for an oke, as I have done ever since I have been here, which is five years. Bread has also not increased, but the cost of meat has greatly increased, and as to house rent it has gone up everywhere. I find that with the utmost economy and going to the bazaar myself the cost of living for food also since last year has increased by otle frane for every six francs spent last year. If the same pro portion is to go on with each year, life will be intolerable for English married people with small incomes. We were unfortunately induced to leave England between five and six years ago because my husband was offered a situation here of £300 a year, while in England we had £180 a year, but we were far better off at home on £180 than we are here on £300 and we enjoyed life far more at home. A person who leaves England for Egypt, and who 18 married, commits a most unwise step if his income is not trebled se an inducement. The cost of living is increasing every day, while the salaries do not keep pace with it, and I should strongly dissuade any friends of mine, contemplating settling in Egypt, unless their income was to be considerably more than doubled.

div.head: GREEK SQUADRON'S DEPARTURE
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE. Dear Sir, I have just read with some surprise that I climbed on to the mast of the small steamer which followed the Greek squadron yesterday afternoon out of Alexandria harbour.
I thank you for this compliment, which, were it exact, would speak highly of my agility, and I cannot help regretting that such was not the case.
I would, I confess it, be quite incapable of performing such a fest I remain, dear Sir,
